sentence1: In the context of Mexican folk music la cancien ranchera is a love song, sung by the common folk, the peasants of the rural countryside.

sentence1: Until you do the arithmetic, you do not realize that, in Lincoln's mind, the critical moment of the founding was 1776, the signing of the Declaration of Independence.
sentence1_translated: Hafi nàwɔ akɔnta la, màde dzesii be le Lincoln ƒe susu me la, ɣeyiɣi vevi si woɖo dukɔa anyi nye ƒe 1776 me, esime woda asi ɖe Ablɔɖeɖegbalẽ si nye Independence Declaration dzi o.
sentence2: Lincoln thought that the nation was truly founded after the election of the first President.

sentence1: Two very old romances still sung in the Southwest are  La Delgadina,  which deals with incest, and  La Aparicien,  which dates from the fifteenth century in Spain.

sentence1: The paradox of the American approach toward equality is that though we trail European societies in our concern about economic equality and wealth discrimination, we lead the world in other areas of egalitarian thinking.

sentence2: America leads European societies in the concern about economic equality.

sentence1: Also in this group is the Twenty-Third Amendment, which extends the right to vote for the president and vice president to citizens otherwise qualified in the District of Columbia.

sentence2: The 23rd amendment says you can vote for the president if you live in California.

sentence2: My uncle used to love Captain Blood and he never left his plantations in Barbados.

sentence2: She had turned towards him despite motioning to leave.

sentence1: Ye'll remember afterwards that it was your hardness drove me.   She moved to depart, then checked, and faced him again.

sentence1: Linked to Nova Scotia by the narrow Chignecto Isthmus, New Brunswick became a separate province in 1784 at the demand of 14,000 Loyalist refugees.
sentence1_translated: Esi Chignecto-ƒugba si le sue la do ka kple Nova Scotia ta la, New Brunswick va zu nuto tɔxɛ aɖe le ƒe 1784 me le asrafo siwo nye nuteƒewɔlawo ƒe nya si sisim wo dometɔ 14,000 bia ta.
sentence2: New Brunswick became a province because it had enough people.
sentence2_translated: New Brunswick va zu nuto elabena ame gbogbo aɖewo nɔ eme.

sentence1: Linked to Nova Scotia by the narrow Chignecto Isthmus, New Brunswick became a separate province in 1784 at the demand of 14,000 Loyalist refugees.

sentence1: Children will enjoy the Cite de la Mer (37 Rue de l'Asile Thomas), with exhibits on the history of boatbuilding, the fishing industry, and how tides and currents shape the coastline.
sentence1_translated: Ðeviwo ade dzi ƒo na wo le Cite de la Mer (Rue de l'Asile Thomas 37), si me woɖe tɔdziʋuwo wɔwɔ ƒe ŋutinya, tɔƒodɔwɔƒe, kple ale si ƒutawo kple ƒutsotsoewo wɔa akpa aɖe le la fia.
sentence2: Kids will like the exhibits about boats.
sentence2_translated: Tɔdziʋuwo ŋuti nu siwo wofiaa ɖeviwo la adze wo ŋu.

sentence1: The Ming Tombs were once a staple of tours to the Great Wall at Badaling, but foreign tourists have seldom been impressed by the site, finding it dank and poorly restored.
sentence1_translated: Tsã la, Ming-ʋɔ si le Badaling la nye teƒe si ame geɖe dea dzi ƒo na wo ne woyi ɖakpɔe, gake ƒãa hafi teƒea wɔa dɔ ɖe dutanyanyuigblɔlawo dzi, elabena teƒea nye teƒe si le tsro eye womegbugbɔ ɖo anyi nyuie o.
sentence2: Only twenty five people visited the Ming Tombs last year.
sentence2_translated: Ame blaeve vɔ atɔ̃ koe yi Ming yɔdoawo me le ƒe si va yi me.

sentence1: The Ming Tombs were once a staple of tours to the Great Wall at Badaling, but foreign tourists have seldom been impressed by the site, finding it dank and poorly restored.

sentence2_translated: Ming yɔdoawo nye teƒe siwo womate ŋu aɖo o le Egipte piramidɔwo me.

sentence1: The best ports in the Mediterranean are June, July, August, and Mae,  said the 16th-century Venetian admiral Andrea Doria, noting that beyond the summer sailing season, a fleet couldn't do better than shelter here.
sentence1_translated: Ƒe alafa 16 lia me Venetia-dziɖula Andrea Doria gblɔ be Mediterranea-ƒukpowo ƒe melidzeƒe nyuitɔwo nye June, July, August, kple Mae, eye wògblɔ be ne wotrɔ yi ƒudzimɔzɔzɔ le dzomeŋɔli la, meliwo mate ŋu awɔ naneke wu be woanɔ afi sia o.
sentence2: Andrea Doria was a great admiral.
sentence2_translated: Andrea Doria nye admiral gã aɖe.

sentence1: Among the 27 hiking trails the best are the Glasgow Lakes trail to John Deer Lake and the trail around Beulach Ban Falls and French Mountain.
sentence1_translated: Le tsaɖiɖi ƒe mɔ 27awo dome la, Glasgow Lakes ƒe mɔ si yi John Deer Ta la dzi kple mɔ si ƒo xlã Beulach Ban Tsiɖɔɖɔ kple French Mountain ye nye nyuitɔ.
sentence2: All of these trails are located within the a one hour drive of each other.
sentence2_translated: Mɔ siawo katã le ʋu me gaƒoƒo ɖeka tso wo nɔewo gbɔ.

sentence1_translated: Le ɣeyiɣi sia me la, susu si le amewo si enye be ɖewohĩ anyo wu be woaɖe asi le ƒukpo sue siwo ŋu wometsi ɖo boo o la ŋu.
sentence2: We should keep the islands involved.
sentence2_translated: Ele be míana ƒukpoawo nakpɔ gome le eme.

sentence1: One inmate returning for the guided tour surprisingly, some do, out of nostalgia said the food was better than he had eaten in many San Francisco hotels.
sentence1_translated: Gamenɔla aɖe si trɔ gbɔ hena mɔzɔzɔ la gblɔ nukutɔe be nuɖuɖu si le afima nyo wu esiwo wòɖuna le San Francisco ƒe amedzrodzeƒe geɖe.
sentence2: Everyone agreed the food was terrible.
sentence2_translated: Amesiame lɔ̃ ɖe edzi be nuɖuɖu la menyo o.

sentence1: One inmate returning for the guided tour surprisingly, some do, out of nostalgia said the food was better than he had eaten in many San Francisco hotels.

sentence1: Even in these early times the gods would be consulted with the oracle issuing their verdicts from the Rock of Sybil.
sentence1_translated: Le blemaŋkeke siawo gɔ̃ hã la, woɖoa gbe ɖe mawunɔwo be woana woƒe nyametsotsowo tso Sybil ƒe agakpe la dzi.
sentence2: The gods always talked to the oracle about every legal matter.
sentence2_translated: Mawuawo ƒoa nu na nyanuɖela ɣesiaɣi le nya sia nya si ku ɖe se ŋu la ŋu.

sentence1: The Baixada de Santa Eulalia descends to carrer dels Banys Nous, named for the long-gone  new  baths of the ghetto erected in the 12th century.

sentence1: Once you're off the traffic-squeezed main arteries, you'll find that Albufeira's old town preserves a surprising bit of traditional charm.
sentence1_translated: Ne èdo go tso mɔ gã siwo me ʋukuku bɔ ɖo la, àkpɔ be Albufeira ƒe du xoxoa gakpɔtɔ léa atsyɔ̃ na wò nukutɔe.
sentence2: Albuferia is bustling and crazy!

sentence1: Close to the original action and still providing the most vivid testimony to the Klondike days, the boomtown of Dawson City yielded in 1951 to the transportation and communications center of Whitehorse as territorial capital.
sentence1_translated: Dawson City si nye du si me nuwo nɔ dzidzim ɖe edzi le la va zu Whitehorse si nye mɔzɔnyawo kple nyatakakamɔnuwo ƒe dɔwɔƒe si nye anyigbaa ƒe fiadu la ƒe fiadu le ƒe 1951 me.
sentence2: Whitehorse used mainly horse carriages for transportation.
sentence2_translated: Sɔviƒolawo zãa sɔwo koŋ tsɔ ʋua wo.

sentence1: Cala Mondrage is practically undeveloped (by the standards of coastal Mallorca), and may stay that way by order of the regional government, which has become alarmed by the specter of unchecked building along the coast.
sentence1_translated: Cala Mondrage mele ŋgɔyiyi aɖeke wɔm o (le Mallorca ƒe ƒuta ƒe dzidzenuwo nu), eye ɖewohĩ aleae wòanɔ le nuto ma me dziɖuɖua ƒe sedede nu, elabena dzi ɖe le wo ƒo le alesi woagava tu xɔ siwo ŋu womekpɔa mɔ ɖo o le ƒuta ta.
sentence2: Cala Mondrage is developed.
sentence2_translated: Wotsɔ Cala Mondrage ɖo teƒe aɖe.

sentence1: It has three meru-topped shrines dedicated to Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu.

sentence1: Less than a mile past the Arboretum, you will find two churches on the right side of the road, backed by hundreds of white painted family tombs on the hillside.
sentence1_translated: Le Arboretum gbɔ vie la, èkpɔ sɔleme eve le mɔa ƒe ɖusime, eye ƒometɔwo ƒe yɔdo alafa geɖe siwo wotsɔ aŋuti ɣi ɖo togbɛa ƒe go dzi la kpe ɖe wo ŋu.
sentence2: The churches are also daycare centers for children.
sentence2_translated: Sɔlemexɔwo hã nyea vidzĩwo ƒe vidzikpɔƒe.

sentence1: The Stampede was originally conceived to show all the techniques and excitement of rounding up cattle on the prairies.
sentence1_translated: Wode asi Stampede zazã me gbã be woatsɔ aɖe lãhawo ƒoƒo ƒu le gbewo dzi ƒe mɔnu kple dzidzɔkpɔkpɔ afia.
sentence2: The Stampede had nothing to do with cattle.

sentence1: Almost 100,000 people a day come here to marvel at the striking architecture and explore the latest attractions in this ever-changing city.

sentence1: Behind the hotel, beyond an 1898 statue of Samuel de Champlain, the city's founder, Dufferin Terrace offers a magnificent view over the St. Lawrence and downriver to the Ile d'Orleans.
sentence1_translated: Dufferin Terrace si le amedzrodzeƒea megbe, si le du sia gɔmeɖola Samuel de Champlain ƒe nɔnɔme aɖe si woɖo le ƒe 1898 me la gbɔ la, na wokpɔa St. Lawrence-tɔsisia kple Île d'Orléans ƒe tɔsisi la ƒe gota nyuie.
sentence2: The statue is made entirely of marble.
sentence2_translated: Kpexɔa katã nye kpe xɔasi.

sentence1: Beyond Payangan, the little-used road wends its way through scenic countryside all the way to Batur (see pagea59).

sentence1: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), founded in 1861 is America's leading science and engineering establishment that has pioneered many modern technologies, from stroboscopic photography to food preservation processes.
sentence1_translated: Massachusetts Mɔ̃ɖaŋununyaƒe (MIT), si woɖo le ƒe 1861 me la nye Amerika ƒe dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunya kple mɔ̃ɖaŋununya ƒe dɔwɔƒe si xɔ ŋgɔ le mɔ̃ɖaŋununya me, eye wònye mɔɖela na mɔ̃ɖaŋununya yeye geɖewo, tso fotowɔwɔ to stroboskopikmɔ̃ dzi va se ɖe nuɖuɖuwo ta kpɔkpɔ me.
sentence2: MIT is where the world's most successful students attend college.
sentence2_translated: MIT enye afisi sukuvi siwo kpɔ dzidzedze wu le xexeame la dea kɔledzi le.

sentence1: Six kilometers (4 miles) north of Ipoh is the Perak Tong, built in 1926 by a Buddhist priest from China.

sentence2: The Perak Tong was built by a Buddhist priest.

sentence1: You can walk the decks or even take a two-hour cruise on this replica of the famous 1921 champion sailship portrayed on the Canadian ten-cent coin.
sentence1_translated: Àte ŋu azɔli le tɔdziʋua ƒe akpa si nèɖo alo nàzɔ tɔdziʋu gaƒoƒo eve gɔ̃ hã le meli sia si nye ƒe 1921 ƒe aʋakalẽtɔ xɔŋkɔ si ƒe nɔnɔmetata le Canada ƒe gaku si ƒe home nye senti ewo la ƒe nɔnɔmetata la dzi.
sentence2: The cruise only last 17 minutes.
sentence2_translated: Tɔdziʋua xɔ miniti 17 pɛ ko.

sentence1: Visitors to the Spectrum section are encouraged to manipulate various machines and participate in scientific experiments.

sentence1: In past centuries, however, it was the haunt of Caribbean pirates, being far from the clutches of colonial overlords in Havana, San Juan in Puerto Rico, and Panama City, the nearest colonial outposts.
sentence1_translated: Gake le ƒe alafa siwo va yi me la, Carib-ƒudzidelawo nɔ afi ma, elabena didi tso aboyomewo ƒe ŋusẽtɔwo si le Havana, San Juan le Puerto Rico, kple Panama City, siwo nye aboyomeawo ƒe nuto siwo te ɖe wo ŋu wu la gbɔ.
sentence2: There have never been pirates in the Caribbean.
sentence2_translated: Ƒudzimɔzɔlawo menɔ Caribbean-ƒukpowo dzi kpɔ o.

sentence1: Tourist offices have tried to rename the area L'Estrie, but even the most militant Quebecois prefer the customary direct, if approximate, translation of the  Cantons de l'Est.
sentence1_translated: Tsaɖilawo ƒe dɔwɔƒewo dze agbagba be yewoatrɔ ŋkɔ na nuto sia be L'Estrie, gake Quebectɔ siwo doa vevie ʋunyaʋunya gɔ̃ hã lɔ̃a Cantons de l'Est ƒe gɔmeɖeɖe si le abe ale si woɖenɛ fiana ene.
sentence2: The tourism people think the area needs a better name because the old one sounds dumpy.
sentence2_translated: Tsaɖilawo susui be ele be woana ŋkɔ bubu teƒea elabena ŋkɔ xoxoa ɖi ƒodo.

sentence1: After two centuries of religious heresy, the Church needed a spiritual renewal, finding the perfect ally in Francis of Assisi (1182-1226), pious without being troublesomely militant.
sentence1_translated: Le subɔsubɔhawo ƒe aʋatsokaka ƒe alafa eve megbe la, Hamea hiã gbɔgbɔ me ɖɔɖɔɖo, eye wòkpɔ kpeɖeŋutɔ deblibo le Francis si tso Assisi (1182-1226) me, amesi nye mawuvɔ̃la evɔ menye aʋawɔla si doa dzre o.
sentence2: The Church got a lot of monetary support from Francis of Assisi.

sentence1: The edifice links two identical churches, the Franzesischer Dom (or French Cathedral) to the north, built for the immigrant Huguenots, and the Deutscher Dom (German Cathedral) to the south.

sentence2_translated: Subɔsubɔhawo katã to vovo.

sentence1: The heart of ancient Athens was centered around the dome of the Acropolis, with sacred temples built atop the rock and the town built on its undulating flanks.
sentence1_translated: Blema Atene ƒe titina nɔ Akropolis ƒe xɔ si ŋu wotu gbedoxɔ kɔkɔwo ɖo ɖe agakpe dzi la ŋu, eye dua hã nɔ eƒe akpa siwo le tsaglãla tsam la dzi.
sentence2: Acropolis was the center and heart of ancient Athens.
sentence2_translated: Acropolis ye nye blema Atene ƒe titina kple eƒe dzi.

sentence1: The heart of ancient Athens was centered around the dome of the Acropolis, with sacred temples built atop the rock and the town built on its undulating flanks.

sentence2: The Acropolis was the most important building in all of Ancient Greeek culture.
sentence2_translated: Akropolis ye nye xɔ vevitɔ kekeake le Helatɔwo ƒe blema dekɔnuwo katã me.

sentence1: The heart of ancient Athens was centered around the dome of the Acropolis, with sacred temples built atop the rock and the town built on its undulating flanks.

sentence1: Under the altar, a silver disc surrounds a hole marking the place where, tradition says, Jesus's cross was raised alongside those of the two thieves on either side.
sentence1_translated: Le vɔsamlekpuia te la, klosalo ƒe nuɖusi aɖe ƒo xlã ʋe si nye afisi wogblɔ le le kɔnyinyi me be, wokɔ Yesu ƒe atitsoga ɖe fiafitɔ eveawo ƒe atitsoga ŋu le le wo dometɔ ɖesiaɖe ƒe axa.
sentence2: The men next to Jesus were bad people.
sentence2_translated: Ame vɔ̃ɖiwoe nɔ Yesu ŋu.

sentence1: Open spaces discovered since the 1960s are now believed to be used for  ball games,  which had an important though as yet only poorly understood ceremonial purpose in Indian culture.
sentence1_translated: Wobu be wotsɔ teƒe siwo ʋuʋu tso ƒe 1960-awo me la wɔ bɔlfefefewo, si nye wɔna vevi aɖe le India-kɔnuwo me, togbɔ be womese nu si wònye hafi o hã.
sentence2: The Indian culture uses ball games as social gatherings.
sentence2_translated: Indiatɔwo zãa bɔlƒoƒo le hadomewɔnawo me.

sentence1: Absent a formal motion to withdraw, an attorney of record in federal court remains responsible, both ethically and under the rules of court, for responding to any matter that should arise.
sentence1_translated: Ne womede asi nya aɖe si wotsɔ ɖe asi me o la, ʋɔnudrɔ̃la si le dukɔa ƒe ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe la nɔa te ɖe seawo kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe ƒe sewo dzi nɔa te ɖe nya sia nya si wòava fɔ ɖe te la dzi.
sentence2: Without a motion to withdraw, an attorney doesn't have to respond to anything.
sentence2_translated: Ne womede asi nya me be woaxɔ nya la o la, mehiã be ame naɖo nya aɖeke ŋu o.

sentence1: Absent a formal motion to withdraw, an attorney of record in federal court remains responsible, both ethically and under the rules of court, for responding to any matter that should arise.
sentence1_translated: Ne womede asi nya aɖe si wotsɔ ɖe asi me o la, ʋɔnudrɔ̃la si le dukɔa ƒe ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe la nɔa te ɖe seawo kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe ƒe sewo dzi nɔa te ɖe nya sia nya si wòava fɔ ɖe te la dzi.
sentence2: Without a motion to withdraw, an attorney is responsible for any response except for one involving citizenship.
sentence2_translated: Ne womede asi nyabiabia me o la, ʋɔnudrɔ̃la la ŋutɔe kpɔa nya sia nya si ame aɖe agblɔ ɖe eŋu la gbɔ, negbe ɖe wòbia be woaxɔ dukɔmevinyenye.

sentence1: G. Burdens of Requiring LSC Funded Attorneys to Withdraw from Cases When the Client Leaves the United States

sentence1: G. Burdens of Requiring LSC Funded Attorneys to Withdraw from Cases When the Client Leaves the United States

sentence1: According to the utility's central information security group, this process increases security awareness among business managers, develops support for needed controls, and helps integrate information security considerations into the organization's business operations.
sentence1_translated: Le nyatakakadzraɖoƒea ƒe nyatakakadzraɖoha ƒe nya nu la, ɖoɖo sia nana dɔwɔƒe dzikpɔlawo dea dzesi nyatakakadzraɖoƒea nyuie, ena wokpɔa mɔ be woawɔ ɖoɖo ɖe nyatakakadzraɖoƒea ŋu, eye wònana wokpɔa nyatakakadzraɖoƒea ƒe dedienɔnɔ ŋuti nukpɔsusuwo le dɔwɔƒea ƒe dɔwɔnawo me.
sentence2: Better security can improve workplace efficiency by 10 percent or more.

sentence1: The program's educational feedback encourages compliance and can act as a deterrent to future wrongdoing, as practitioners are aware that HIC tracks what is claimed for reimbursement on an annual basis.

sentence2_translated: Ame siwo ɖea wo ɖokui le wo ɖokui si le Amerika la dometɔ akpa gãtɔ lɔ̃a nu sia wɔwɔ.

sentence1: 20 Conversely, dissaving-spending more than current income-reduces the stock of wealth because amounts saved in the past must be drawn down, existing assets sold, or borrowing increased.
sentence1_translated: 20 Gake ne míedzudzɔ ga si míedzra ɖo - si nye ga si míezã wu ga si míexɔna fifia - la, ga si míedzra ɖo le ɣeyiɣi siwo va yi me la dzi ɖeɖena, elabena ele be míazã ga siwo míedzra ɖo le ɣeyiɣi siwo va yi me, adzra nu siwo le mía si, alo míado ga geɖe.
sentence2: Dissaving means you save a ton of money.
sentence2_translated: Ne èɖe asi le eŋu la, àkpɔ ga geɖe.

sentence1: It would be extremely difficult for a legal services attorney in California to know whether a client, who has been working in the migrant stream in Arizona, has temporarily crossed the border into Mexico.

sentence1: One agency intended to implement an employee travel claim procedure allowing travelers, with certain exceptions, to merely list an aggregate amount of all expenses that individually cost $75 or less.
sentence1_translated: Dɔwɔƒe aɖe ɖoe be yeawɔ dɔwɔla ƒe mɔzɔzɔ ŋuti nyatakakawo ŋuti ɖoɖo aɖe si ana mɔzɔlawo, ne woɖe mɔnu aɖewo ɖa ko la, woaŋlɔ ga siwo katã wozã ɖe mɔzɔzɔa ŋu siwo ƒe home mede dɔlar 75 alo esi mede nenema o la ƒe xexlẽme katã ko.
sentence2: One agency tried to make it so that an employee can just claim any travel expenses under $75 under an aggregate amount.
sentence2_translated: Dɔwɔƒe aɖe dze agbagba be yeana dɔwɔla aɖe nabia mɔzɔzɔ fe siwo mede dɔlar 75 o la ko le ga home ɖeka me.

sentence1: The inability to communicate was a critical element at the World Trade Center, Pentagon, and Somerset County, Pennsylvania, crash sites, where multiple agencies and multiple jurisdictions responded.
sentence1_translated: Kadodo ƒe manyamanya nye nu vevi aɖe le Xexea Me Asitsatsaƒe, Pentagon, kple Somerset County, Pennsylvania, afisi afɔku dzɔ le, afisi dɔwɔƒe kple ʋɔnudrɔ̃ƒe geɖe wɔ dɔ le.
sentence2: Communication worked really well on 9/11.
sentence2_translated: Dzeɖoɖo dze edzi nyuie le 9/11.

sentence1: Our borders and immigration system, including law enforcement, ought to send a message of welcome, tolerance, and justice to members of immigrant communities in the United States and in their countries of origin.

sentence2: Our country should make it clear they welcome immigrants.

sentence1: Our borders and immigration system, including law enforcement, ought to send a message of welcome, tolerance, and justice to members of immigrant communities in the United States and in their countries of origin.

sentence1: With respect to KSM's additional proposal to bomb cargo planes by shipping jackets containing nitrocellulose, KSM states that Bin Ladin expressed interest in changing the operation so that it would involve a suicide operative.

sentence1: We recognize that a costly change in NORAD's defense posture to deal with the danger of suicide hijackers, before such a threat had ever actually been realized, would have been a tough sell.

sentence1: Yousef managed to escape to Pakistan, but his accomplice, Murad-whom KSM claims to have sent to Yousef with $3,000 to help fund the operation-was arrested and disclosed details of the plot while under interrogation.

sentence2: Murad revealed information about the plan when interrogated.
sentence2_translated: Esi wobia gbe Murad la, eɖe nu me tso ɖoɖo si wowɔ ŋu.

sentence2: I hated going to theater shows as a kid, so that's why I became a scientist.
sentence2_translated: Melé fu fefewo kpɔkpɔ le nye ɖevime, eya ta meva zu dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyala.

sentence1: School of Nursing needs your generous gifts to continue and uphold its educational excellence.

sentence1: We invite you to participate in Futures for Children by sponsoring an American Indian child or by joining a Membership Circle to support our community education projects.
sentence1_translated: Míele kpewòm be nàkpe asi ɖe Futures for Children ŋu to Amerikatɔwo ƒe Indiatɔ aɖe dzi kpɔkpɔ me alo to hadede kple hamevi aɖewo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo aɖe me be nàkpe asi ɖe míaƒe nutowo me sukudenyawo ŋu.
sentence2: If you choose to sponsor an American Indian child you will not be allowed to participate in Futures for Children.
sentence2_translated: Ne ètiae be yeakpe asi ɖe Amerikatɔwo ƒe Indiatɔ aɖe ŋu la, womana mɔ wò be nàde Futures for Children ƒe kpekpea o.

sentence1: I am therefore delighted to extend this invitation today giving you the opportunity to join us as a Charter Associate of the Center on Philanthropy.

sentence1: Ticket sales and subscriptions cannot finance our complete season

sentence1: The law school's needs range from purchasing additional computer terminals to paying travel costs of our moot court teams and from refurbishing the Gray Lounge to purchasing necessary reference materials for the library.

sentence2: Only half of the law school's computers are still functional.

sentence1: Our Civil Practice Clinic has operated for several years, and we recently added a Criminal Defense Clinic.
sentence1_translated: Míaƒe Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ƒe Dɔwɔƒe la le dɔ wɔm ƒe geɖee nye esia, eye nyitsɔ laa la, míetsɔ Dzɔdzɔmeŋutinunyalawo ƒe Dɔwɔƒe hã kpe ɖe eŋu.

sentence2_translated: Pokemon le agbe eye wòle lãmesẽ me eye mekpɔa teƒe aɖeke na nu bubu siwo ate ŋu ahe ga vɛ o.

sentence1: Still, the inevitable death of Pokemon presents us with the opportunity to create the replacement phenom and cash in on it.
sentence1_translated: Ke hã, Pokemon ƒe ku si nu womate ŋu axe mɔ ɖo o la naa mɔnukpɔkpɔ mí be míatu teƒeɖoɖonuwo eye míazã wo atsɔ akpɔ viɖe.
sentence2: With Pokemon dying out, a new opportunity to profit off a replacement is evident.
sentence2_translated: Esi Pokemon le kukum ta la, mɔnukpɔkpɔ yeye aɖe li si dzi woato akpɔ viɖe tso wo ɖɔla yeyewo gbɔ.

sentence1: Pamela Harriman, the U.S. ambassador to France, legendary Democratic Party financier, and serial wife and lover to great men of the 20 th century, died of a brain hemorrhage at 76.
sentence1_translated: Pamela Harriman, amesi nye Amerika ƒe duta le France, si nye Demokratɔwo ƒe habɔbɔa ƒe gakɔntametola xɔŋkɔ, si nye ame siwo ƒe srɔ̃ kple lɔlɔ̃ le ƒe alafa 20 lia me la dometɔ geɖe, ku le ahɔhɔ̃ me ʋusisidɔ si wòxɔ le ƒe 76 me ta.
sentence2: Harriman has been married a lot of times.
sentence2_translated: Harriman ɖe srɔ̃ zi geɖe.

sentence1: Just regarding the complaint about reliance on girlfriends, though, Prudie suggests you have a loooong and serious heart-to-heart with your wife, outlining your disturbance with her choices.

sentence2: Prudie says you should keep it to yourself.

sentence1: Obviously, being fairly arbitrary, many of the AFI choices may not lend themselves to sound cultural interpretation.
sentence1_translated: Edze ƒã be esi wònye be AFI ƒe tiatiawo nye nu si sɔ ta la, ɖewohĩ womate ŋu aɖe nu si tututu wole wɔwɔm la gɔme nyuie o.
sentence2: A study of culture based on AFI choices could lead to some sharply contradictory interpretations.
sentence2_translated: AFI ƒe tiatiawo dzi wɔwɔ ate ŋu ana woase nu gɔme na ame le mɔ si mesɔ o nu.

sentence1: Obviously, being fairly arbitrary, many of the AFI choices may not lend themselves to sound cultural interpretation.

sentence1: Walcott trained to be a painter--like his schoolteacher father, who died when Walcott was a baby--and The Bounty is his most painterly book, in method and theme.
sentence1_translated: Walcott xɔ hehe be wòanye nutatawɔla - abe fofoa si nye sukunufiala, si ku esime Walcott nye vidzĩ ene - eye The Bounty nye eƒe agbalẽ si me nuwɔwɔ nyuie le le mɔ kple nyatiwo me.
sentence2: Walcott's father did not know how to paint.
sentence2_translated: Walcott fofo menya nu si ƒomevi woatia be yeawɔ o.

sentence1: Whatever happened to the military's traditional heartless approach of finding a scapegoat?
sentence1_translated: Nukae dzɔ ɖe asrafowo ƒe nuwɔna si me nublanuikpɔkpɔ mele o si nye be woakpɔ nuvɔ̃kpe la dzi?
sentence2: Changes in military traditions are evident as fewer scapegoats are used to explain problems with discipline and command.

sentence1: Newsweek 's cover story argues that North America was first peopled by a Rainbow Coalition of ethnic types, not just the Bering Strait-crossing Asians commonly depicted in history textbooks.
sentence1_translated: Newsweek ƒe akpaa dzi nya gblɔ be dukɔ siwo ƒo ƒu wɔ dukɔwo ƒe ƒuƒoƒo aɖe si nye Rainbow Coalition ye nɔ Dziehe Amerika gbã, ke menye Asiatɔ siwo to Bering tɔsisia me abe ale si woɖenɛ fiana le ŋutinyagbalẽwo me ene o.
sentence2: Asians are not represented in history textbooks.
sentence2_translated: Womegblɔa Asiatɔwo ŋkɔ le ŋutinyagbalẽwo me o.

sentence1: We've become so accustomed to hearing U.S. companies complain about foreign competition that it's easy to see Kodak's post-defeat recriminations as just more whining.

sentence2: Foreign competition will destroy U.S. companies.
sentence2_translated: Dukɔwo me hoʋiʋli agblẽ Amerika-dɔwɔƒewo dome.

sentence1: The body of Dowd's work as a columnist, and in particular the Flytrap pieces that won her the Pulitzer, is one of the most brilliant examples yet of boomer self-castigation.
sentence1_translated: Dɔ siwo Dowd wɔ abe nyadzɔdzɔŋlɔla ene, vevietɔ Flytrap si na wòxɔ Pulitzer la nye kpɔɖeŋu nyui siwo ɖee fia be ame siwo tsi le ƒea ƒe gɔmedzedze la dea bubu wo ɖokui ŋu.
sentence2: Dowd has never and will never write anything that could be construed as boomer self-castigation.
sentence2_translated: Dowd meŋlɔ nu aɖeke kpɔ o eye maŋlɔe hã gbeɖe o si woate ŋu abu be enye ame siwo tsi agbe la ƒe ɖokuidodo ɖe dzi me.

sentence1: As it happens, of course, there are more distinctive dialects of English in Britain than in North America, and anyone who has spent any time listening to them knows that some are mutually unintelligible.

sentence2: Britain has many distinctive English dialects, numbering more than those in North America.

sentence1: For example, diagnosis was borrowed from a Greek word (which, incidentally, did not mean the same thing); two hundred years afterwards, the verb diagnose --a back formation --was coined.

sentence1: Speakers who want to impress their audiences know they have to telegraph key points and facts, then announce them, then repeat, dramatize, explain, and embellish.

sentence1: One of the linguistic phenomena to have emerged during the last hundred years or so is the acceptance of the notion that an important step in solving problems lies in naming them.
sentence1_translated: Gbegbɔgblɔ me nudzɔdzɔ siwo do mo ɖa le ƒe alafa ɖeka siwo va yi me dometɔ ɖekae nye nukpɔsusu si nye be woana ŋkɔ kuxiwo le mɔ vevi aɖe nu.
sentence2: It is generally accepted that one of the most important steps to solving a problem is first to name it.
sentence2_translated: Wonyae be afɔ vevi siwo woazã hafi akpɔ kuxi aɖe gbɔ dometɔ ɖekae nye be woana ŋkɔe gbã.

sentence1: One of the linguistic phenomena to have emerged during the last hundred years or so is the acceptance of the notion that an important step in solving problems lies in naming them.

sentence2: It is generally agreed that there is no point in naming a problem, because it wastes time while new problems arise and change before solutions can be found.

sentence2: We only use the historic spellings.
